definition: to endure humiliation as part of an important mission (idiom); to suffer in silence
to bear/to endure/to tolerate/to restrain oneself
disgrace/dishonor/to insult/to bring disgrace or humiliation to/to be indebted to/self-deprecating/Taiwan pr. [ru4]
to bear/to carry (on one's back)/to turn one's back on/to be defeated/negative (math. etc)
heavy/serious/to attach importance to
to repeat/repetition/again/re-/classifier: layer

sentences.english: What we Chinese do best, is to endure.
sentences.chinese: 中国人是最能忍辱负重的人民。

sentences.english: Get plank brick this matter, if stem good, call to meekly tolerate insult negative heavy.
sentences.chinese: 挨板砖这事，如果干得好，叫忍辱负重。

sentences.english: Why do we have to live like this when we don't want to?
sentences.chinese: 为什么人一定要忍辱负重地活着？

sentences.english: Our future life is an important power, is called a humiliation.
sentences.chinese: 我们未来生活的一种重要能力，叫做忍辱负重的能力。

sentences.english: For people, to endure humiliation is another moral integrity.
sentences.chinese: 为了人民的事业，忍辱负重，也是另一种骨气。

sentences.english: Under those circumstances, I had to put my pride in my pocket.
sentences.chinese: 在那种情况下，我必须忍辱负重。

definition: to bear humiliation to save one's skin (idiom)
to bear patiently/to endure silently/to forbear
lit. to sleep on brushwood and taste gall (like King Gou Jian of Yue 勾踐|勾践[Gou1 Jian4]), in order to recall one's humiliations) (idiom)/fig. to maintain one's resolve for revenge
lit. to lie on firewood and taste gall (idiom); fig. suffering patiently, but firmly resolved on revenge
to accept a compromise
to drift and live without purpose (idiom); to drag out an ignoble existence
to conceal one's strengths and bide one's time (idiom)/to hide one's light under a bushel
to submit to humiliation (idiom); to suffer in silence/to swallow one's anger/to grin and bear it
to bear shame and humiliation (idiom)
to eat humble pie/to accept humiliation/to turn the other cheek
willingly
to take the big picture into consideration (idiom)/to work for the benefits of all
can bow and submit, or can stand tall (idiom, from Book of Changes); ready to give and take/flexible
to make painstaking efforts (idiom); after much trouble/to work hard at sth
to humiliate/humiliating
to have a high notion of one's duty/to be highly principled
to bow and bend the knee (idiom); fawning/bending and scraping to curry favor
